content.p: Human cells have an internal solute concentration of approximately 1%. This solute concentration includes salts, sugars, proteins, and all the other molecules dissolved in the cytoplasm.

question.body: What is the internal water concentration of a cell with an internal solute concentration of 1%?

multiple_choice.choice: It is not possible to determine from the information given.

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is the internal solute concentration.
Correct. If there is 1% solute in a solution, the other 99% must be water!
Incorrect. This is the total concentration of solute + water.
Incorrect. The solute concentration + water concentration = 100%

part.hint: The internal water concentration would be 100% - (the internal solute concentration).
The internal water concentration would be 100% - 1%

question.body: What external solute concentration is isotonic to the cell above?

response.feedback: Correct. A solution that is isotonic to this cell will have the SAME concentration as the cell!
Incorrect. This is the concentration of water. What is the concentration of solute?
Incorrect. This is the total concentration of solute + water.

part.hint: Isotonic means the cell and environment have the same solute concentration.
The solute concentration of the cell is 1%.
To be isotonic, the external environment also needs to be 1% solute concentration.

question.body: In an isotonic situation, which way will water flow?

multiple_choice.choice: Equally into and out of the cell.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Water tends to move down its own concentration gradient. But in an isotonic solution, there is no gradient: solute concentrations outside and inside the cell are equal.
Incorrect. Water tends to move down its own concentration gradient. But in an isotonic solution, there is no gradient: solute concentrations outside and inside the cell are equal.
Correct. Solute concentrations are equal inside and outside the cell. There will be no net flow of water; water molecules will move at equal rates both into and out of the cell.

part.hint: Water moves from high concentration to low concentration.
The cell and external environment are equal concentrations.
Therefore water will not have a net movement in either direction.
